name: OpenAPI Specification - Version 3.0.3 | Swagger

name: Open API - Wikipedia
snippet: An open API (often referred to as a public API) is a publicly available application programming interface that provides developers with programmatic access to a proprietary software application or web service. APIs are sets of requirements that govern how one application can communicate and interact with another. APIs can also allow developers to access certain internal functions of a program ...

name: Develop ASP.NET Core apps using OpenAPI | Microsoft Docs
snippet: Adding an OpenAPI reference using any of the commands on this page adds an <OpenApiReference /> element similar to the following to the .csproj file: <OpenApiReference Include="openapi.json" /> The preceding reference is required for the app to call the generated client code.

name: OpenAPI Specification - Wikipedia
snippet: The OpenAPI Specification, originally known as the Swagger Specification, is a specification for machine-readable interface files for describing, producing, consuming, and visualizing RESTful web services. Originally part of the Swagger framework, it became a separate project in 2016, overseen by the OpenAPI Initiative, an open-source collaboration project of the Linux Foundation.

name: OpenAPI.Tools

name: Understanding gRPC, OpenAPI and REST and when to use them ...

name: What Is the Difference Between Swagger and OpenAPI?

name: Basic Structure - Swagger
snippet: The OpenAPI version defines the overall structure of an API definition – what you can document and how you document it. OpenAPI 3.0 uses semantic versioning with a three-part version number. The available versions are 3.0.0, 3.0.1, 3.0.2, and 3.0.3; they are functionally the same.

name: What is OpenAPI? | OpenAPI Definition | API Glossary
snippet: What is OpenAPI? name: About - OpenAPI Initiative

name: Introduction to the OpenAPI specification | Documenting APIs
snippet: OpenAPI is a specification for describing REST APIs. If you’re familiar with tech comm specifications, you can think of the OpenAPI specification like the DITA specification. With DITA, there are specific XML elements used to define help components, and a required order and hierarchy to those elements. Different tools can read DITA and build out a documentation website from the elements.

name: OpenAPI - ReadMe

Version 3.0.0 was released under the name OpenAPI Specification 3.0.0.
